questions.text: A patient presents with a visibly curved nasal dorsum along the midline, extending from the frontonasal angle to the nasal tip as shown below. What is the most appropriate term to describe this nasal deformity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a crooked nose, the midline of the dorsum from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner.
  • The midline is not straight; both bone and cartilage may be affected.
  • The curve usually extends from the frontonasal angle to the tip.

Explanation of other options:

Saddle nose (Option A): It refers to a depression or collapse of the nasal bridge. Caused by loss of septal or bony support (e.g., leprosy, trauma, septal abscess, congenital syphilis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis). Not characterised by curvature but rather by flattening of the dorsum.

Hump nose(Option B): Refers to a prominent dorsal hump over the nasal bridge, formed by excess bone or cartilage. Often due to trauma or genetic causes, the dorsum is raised, not curved or deviated.

Deviated nose (Option D): Usually referred to as Deviated nasal septum for the internal deviation of the nasal septum, which may or may not be externally visible.

questions.text: A Deviated Nasal Septum can lead to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nasal polyps form due to allergy or chronic inflammation. DNS cannot lead to polyp formation.

Clinical features of DNS (Deviated Nasal Septum):

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Headache - due to a spur pressing the lateral wall of the nose or sinusitis (Option A)
  • Sinusitis - By obstructing the opening of the sinus ostia (Option B)
  • Epistaxis - drying effects of air currents on a deviated septum lead to crust formation, which, when removed, cause bleeding.
  • Anosmia/ Hyposmia - due to failure of the inspired air to reach the olfactory region (Option D)
  • External Deformity
  • Middle Ear Infection
  • Inferior turbinate hypertrophy on the roomier side.

Explanation:

  • β2 transferrinis a protein seen in CSF and not in nasal discharge. Its presence is a specific and sensitive test and requires only a few drops of CSF. Perilymph and aqueous humour are the only other fluids that contain this protein.
  • Another protein called beta trace proteinis also specific for CSF and is widely used in Europe. It is secreted by the meninges and the choroid plexus.

choices.text: Repair of the leak site endoscopically

questions.text: You are an ENT surgeon. A patient with a traumatic head injury presents to you after two weeks with a watery nasal discharge that cannot be sniffed back. He visited a general physician two weeks ago and was put on bed rest and antibiotics. What is your treatment approach now?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A watery nasal discharge that cannot be sniffed back following head trauma is CSF rhinorrhea.

Tests For Localisation of Site of Leak:

  • Nasal endoscopy can be done to identify the site of leak and for its repair.
  • High-resolution CT scan - important to see the bony defects.
  • MRI- requires that the CSF leak is active at the time of scan.
  • Intrathecal fluorescein study- Dye appears bright yellow, but when seen with a blue filter, it appears fluorescent green.

Initial management is conservative:

  • Bed rest, antibiotics, elevating the head of the bed, stool softeners, and avoidance of nose blowing, sneezing and straining.
  • If it does not resolve in 7- 10 days, surgical repair is planned.

Transnasal endoscopic approach:

  • Preferred modality these days. Most of the leaks from the anterior cranial fossa and sphenoid sinus can be managed endoscopically with a success rate of 90%.
  • Cartilage graft - If the bony defect is larger than 2 cm, it is repaired with cartilage (from nasal septum or auricular concha), followed by placement of mucosa.
  • Fascial graft - Fascia can be obtained from the thigh. Or fat from the thigh or abdomen can be used.

Explanation of other options:

  • Wait and watch for 7-10 days(Option A):Appropriate for early/acute leaks (<7-10 days), especially in closed head injuries without complications.But this patient has already had 2 weeks of conservative therapy without resolution so surgery is now indicated.
  • Pack the nasal cavity immediately(Option C):Nasal packing is contraindicated in CSF leaks as it may increase intracranial pressure,risk meningitis and cause further trauma.
  • Mitomycin-C therapy(Option D): It is used in ENT mainly for preventing adhesions (e.g., in laryngeal/tracheal stenosis, after sinus surgery)
  • It has no role in CSF leak management.

questions.text: Which of the following shows the given finding on filter paper?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a Double target sign seen from CSF rhinorrhea in traumatic CSF leak.
  • CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood and shows this sign when collected on a piece of filter paper, i.e. central red spot and peripheral lighter halo.
  • Cribriform plate (ethmoid bone) is the most common site, with fovea ethmoidalis as a secondary site.

choices.text: Horizontal # of the nasal septum due to trauma from the Front
Vertical # of nasal septum due to trauma from below
Horizontal # of the nasal septum with trauma from below
Vertical # of nasal septum with trauma from the front

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chevallet's fracture results from trauma directed upward, causing a vertical split in the nasal septum, often associated with nasal bone fractures.

Fractures of Nasal Septum:

questions.text: A patient of nasal trauma presents to an ENT specialist. X-ray nasal bone shows a nasal bone fracture. The fracture reduction is being planned. The surgeon uses the forceps shown in the given picture. What is the name of these forceps?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Luc's forceps (Option C): Used in Caldwell-Luc operation (to remove mucosa), submucosal resection (SMR) operation (to remove bone or cartilage), polypectomy (to grasp and avulse polyps) and to take a biopsy from the nose or throat

Freer's double-ended elevator (Option D): Used for elevation of mucoperichondrium or periosteum in SMR or septoplasty operation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male sustains nasal trauma from a cricket bat, causing epistaxis (now resolved), nasal deformity, and crepitus with swelling on palpation. The X-ray Nasal bone lateral view is shown in the image below. What is the ideal time for fracture reduction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Reduction is best within 1-2 hours if no oedema, or after 5-7 days if oedema is present.
  • The nasal bones are the most commonly fractured bones of the face because of the projection of the nose on the face.
  • It is difficult to reduce a nasal fracture after 2 weeks because the process of callus formation would have started.

questions.text:
All are true about mandible fracture except:
a. The condylar neck is the most common site
b. Malocclusion of teeth may occur
c. Anterior superior alveolar nerve is most commonly injured
d. Panorex radiographs are useful for diagnosis
e. Malunion & non-union are complications
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The anterior superior alveolar nerve supplies the upper jaw and is not injured in a mandibular fracture.
  • In fracture of mandible, the Condyle is the most commonly fractured, followed by the Angle, Body and Symphysis (CABS). (Statement a)
  • Malocclusion of teeth and deviation of the jaw to the opposite side occur in displaced fractures of the condyle. (Statement b)
  • Panoramic radiography (Orthopantomogram / OPG) is a standard, effective imaging method to assess the entire mandible in one film.(Statement d)
  • Malunion & non-union are well-known complications of mandibular fractures, especially with poor fixation, infection, or delayed treatment.(Statement e)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the fracture shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows a Zygomatic (Tripod) fracture. There is no CSF leak as the skull base is not damaged in this fracture.
  • It can have:
    • Trismus (Option A ruled out) due to depression of the zygomaon the underlying coronoid process
    • Fracture of the infraorbital margin causing step deformity.
    • Flattening of the malar eminence.
    • Cheek anaesthesia (Option C ruled out) is due to injury of the Infraorbital nerve.
    • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of the lateral palpebral ligament.
    • Entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle > diplopia. (Option B ruled out)
    • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

choices.text: Le Fort fractures are classified into five distinct types
Le Fort I involves craniofacial disjunction
Le Fort II and III may be associated with CSF rhinorrhea
Le Fort fractures primarily involve the zygomatic bone

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Le Fort fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Le Fort II, III fractures can cause CSF rhinorrhea. Le Fort I does not.

Le Fort Fracture:

  • It is a fracture of the maxilla. (Option D)
  • Three types: (Option A)
    • Le Fort type I:
      • Horizontal fracture, separating the teeth from the upper face
      • Fracture runs above and parallel to the palate. It crosses the lower part of the nasal septum, the maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
    • Le Fort type II:
      • Pyramidal fracture, with the teeth at the pyramid base, and the nasofrontal suture at its apex
      • Fracture arch passes through the posterior alveolar ridge, the lateral walls of the maxillary sinuses, the inferior orbital rim andthe nasal bones
    • Le Fort type III:
      • Craniofacial disjunction (Option B)
      • The transverse fracture line passes through the nasofrontal suture, maxillo-frontal suture, orbital wall, and zygomatic arch / zygomaticofrontal suture
      • Because of the involvement of the zygomatic arch, there is a risk of the temporalis muscle impingement

questions.text: In a fracture maxilla most commonly involved nerve is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary division (V2) of the trigeminal nerve, passes through the infraorbital foramen in the maxilla.
  • It is the most commonly injured nerve in maxillary fractures, especially Le Fort fractures, due to its anatomical course along the orbital floor and anterior maxillary wall.
  • Injury leads to numbness or paresthesia over the cheek, upper lip, and upper gingiva.
